authorsByline: Max Goodman | mgoodman@njadvancemedia.com, maxgoodman, Max Goodman
title: Grieving Jazz Chisholm lifted Yankees with milestone home runs
description: The New York Yankees ended their losing streak against the Boston Red Sox on Sunday night at Yankee Stadium.
content:
Jazz Chisholm hit the 100th and 101st home runs of his career on Sunday, one day after the passing of his best friend. AP

NEW YORK — Jazz Chisholm Jr. shook his head and leaned down as he buried his face into Aaron Judge’s chest, getting a big hug in the Yankees’ dugout.

Chisholm had just circled the bases after the 100th home run of his big-league career, his first of two blasts in Sunday night’s much-needed win over the Red Sox. In that moment, however, the second baseman’s mind was elsewhere.

“It felt kind of surreal,” Chisholm said. “I lost my best friend yesterday. Today felt like a different type of day, especially with the 100th home run coming today and everything.”

Chisholm was asked for more details about his best friend, but he explained that he’d like to keep it all private, at least for now.

“I’m going through a lot in the last 30 hours,” he said.

Chisholm’s milestone homer came in his first at-bat of the night, a towering two-run shot to right field off Red Sox righty Dustin May.

He then swatted another two-run blast in the eighth, a low line drive over the short porch off right-hander Walker Buehler that gave the Yankees a few more valuable insurance runs. They went on to win 7-2.

“It makes it feel even better that we won the game, especially against the team that’s really been beating us a lot this year,” Chisholm said. “That should take us into a good momentum right now.”

The Yankees had lost eight games in a row against Boston before their victory on Sunday night. They’ll welcome the last-place Nationals into town on Monday for a three-game set as the Yankees wrap up their homestand.

If the Yankees can continue to score runs like they did on Sunday — Trent Grisham also hit two homers and Giancarlo Stanton stayed hot at the plate — then they’ll be in good shape to start rattling off some wins leading into the final month of the regular season.

“When everything’s going well, that’s how we are,” Chisholm said. “We hit homers, we score a lot of runs and we walk a lot. I feel like that was our game tonight. We had a lot of walks, hit a couple home runs and played great defense. That’s what we’re really known for.”

Thank you for relying on us to provide the journalism you can trust. Please consider supporting us with a subscription.

Max Goodman may be reached at mgoodman@njadvancemedia.com.
summary: Jazz Chisholm Jr. hit the 100th and 101st home runs of his career in a game against the Red Sox, one day after his best friend passed away. The milestone home runs came in the same day as Chishesolm's 100th home run. The Yankees won 7-2 over Boston, marking their first win in eight games in a row against Boston. The team's win was significant for the team, which had lost eight consecutive games against Boston and will welcome the last-place Nationals in town for a three-game set.
shortSummary: Jazz Chisholm Jr. led the Yankees with 100th and 101st home runs, one day after his best friend's death, leading to a 7-2 win over Boston.

scraped_sources.text:
NEW YORK — In a year where the Yankees already cornered the market on mental mistakes, failing to hit when it counts and otherwise working their way down the ladder of success, here’s the ultimate badge of dishonor:
They’ve been embarrassed by the Red Sox in what was supposed to be the season’s biggest series. Three games so far, three demoralizing losses, a million reasons to believe this team is going nowhere in October.

NEW YORK —Yankees captain Aaron Judge took the next step in his throwing program on Sunday afternoon, making throws from right field to second base for the first time this month.
Judge had been building up to around 150 feet in his long-toss program as he continues to build back up from a right flexor strain.

Here’s an MLB story via the Associated Press:
NEW YORK (AP) — Garrett Crochet struck out 11 in seven innings, Trevor Story homered and drove in three runs, and the Boston Red Sox beat the New York Yankees 12-1 on Saturday.
Star rookie Roman Anthony and Alex Bregman each drove in a run for Boston, which defeated New York for the eighth straight time after losing the rivals’ first meeting on June 6. The Red Sox, second in the NL East to Toronto, moved 1 1/2 games ahead of the Yankees in the division. Boston and New York are both in position for wild-card playoff spots.
Crochet (14-5) took over the major league lead in both innings (166 1/3) and strikeouts (207). The left-hander allowed five hits, including Giancarlo Stanton’s 16th homer.
Crochet became the first Boston pitcher since Eduardo Rodríguez in 2019 to surpass 200 strikeouts in a season. He also exceeded 500 K’s for his career.
Story had a two-run double in the third inning against rookie Will Warren (7-6) and hit his 20th homer on Warren’s first pitch of the fifth.
Yankees slugger Aaron Judge went 1 for 4 with a double but struck out twice and is hitting .218 since being activated from the injured list on Aug. 5. New York has dropped three straight following a five-game winning streak.
Boston scored seven runs in the ninth, when Yankees shortstop Anthony Volpe committed his major league-leading 17th error and Carlos Narváez homered.
Key moment
New York trailed 5-1 in the eighth when Judge and Cody Bellinger had back-to-back one-out hits against Greg Weissert. The right-hander struck out Stanton and Justin Wilson struck out pinch-hitter Jazz Chisolm Jr. to end the threat.
The right-hander struck out two batters to end the threat.
Key stat
Story (32 years, 282 days) became the oldest Red Sox player to record 20 homers and 20 stolen bases in a season.
Up next
Dustin May (7-9, 4.59) ERA pitches for the Red Sox as they go for a sweep against the Yankees’ Carlos Rodón (13-7, 3.24).
(The Associated Press contributed to this report).

NEW YORK — Anthony Volpe is on the Yankees’ bench for Sunday’s series finale against the Red Sox and it’s not because he’s getting a day off.
He’s not hurt either.

argos_summary: Jazz Chisholm Jr. hit his 100th and 101st career home runs in a Yankees victory over the Red Sox, celebrating the milestones while coping with the recent loss of his best friend. He opened the game with a two‑run homer and followed it up with another in the eighth inning, helping the Yankees break an eight‑game losing streak against Boston. The win, marked by strong offensive and defensive play, provides a positive momentum for the Yankees as they head into the final stretch of the season.
